10.1016/j.apcata.2022.118639 Fig. 1 (a) UV-Vis spectra of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors; (b) PXRD patterns of the Zr(OH)4 and ZrO2 samples (ZrO2-Ⅰ and ⅠⅠ are obtained by calcining the purchased Zr(OH)4 and ZrO2, respectively (700 °C for 240 min)); (c) PXRD patterns of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors; (d-f) TEM images of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors (d: Y25Z75-ZrO2; e: Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4; f: Y25Z75-CP). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) N2-sorption isotherms and (b) BJH pore size distributions on the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors; (c) N2-sorption isotherms and (d) BJH pore size distributions (b) on the NY25Z75 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the fresh (a) and reduced (b) NY25Z75 catalysts; TEM images (c-d) and Ni particle size distributions (f-h) of the reduced catalysts (c and f: NY25Z75-ZrO2; d and g: NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4; e and h: NY25Z75-CP). Red circles in Figures c-e indicate Ni particles. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) CO2-TPD profiles, (b) O2-TPD profiles and (c) O 1s spectra of the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of Zr 3d (a), Y 3d (b) and Ni 2p3/2 (c) on the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts; (d) H2-TPR profiles of the fresh NY25Z75 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Profiles of CH4-TPSR over the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a)-(c) The initial DRM activity of the NY25Z75 catalysts at different temperatures (Reaction conditions: atmospheric atmosphere, CH4/CO2 =1, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV)= 48,000 mL·g−1·h−1); (d-f) Performance of the NY25Z75 catalysts in DRM (Reaction conditions: T = 700 °C, atmospheric atmosphere, CH4/CO2 =1, WHSV=48,000 mL·g−1·h−1). (a) and (d): CH4 conversion; (b) and (e): CO2 conversion; (c) and (f): H2/CO ratio. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) XRD patterns, (b) Raman spectra, (c) TG profiles and (d) DTG profiles of the NY25Z75 catalysts after the activity evaluation. State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China The surface reactive oxygen species over Y2O3-ZrO2 supports were tuned by regulating the interaction between Y and Zr via modulating the zirconium precursors. It was revealed that the content of the surface adsorbed oxygen species (SAOS) over the catalyst with ZrO2 precursor was the highest, followed by the catalysts with Zr(OH)4 and ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O precursors. The difference of the Y-Zr interaction influenced the reactive oxygen species and the support structure and morphology. However, Ni dispersion was determined by the existence of the isolated Y2O3 due to the enhanced metal-support interaction. High Ni dispersion and abundant surface adsorbed oxygen species were beneficial to promote CH4 and CO2 reactivity. Nevertheless, CH4 dissociation facilitated by the SAOS was more remarkable than CO2 activation at low temperature. Thus, the improvement of the SAOS on carbon-resistant ability of the catalyst was only achieved at high temperature through balancing the carbon formation and elimination. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Dry reforming Y2O3-ZrO2 support Zirconium precursor Oxygen species Spillover 1 Introduction As a promising route to simultaneously convert two greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) into the highly-value-added syngas (CO+H2), dry reforming of methane (DRM, Eq. 1) has attracted more and more attention in the past decades [1,2]. Although the inexpensive Ni catalysts exhibit the comparable activity to the noble metal catalysts, the severe deactivation caused by Ni particle sintering and carbon deposition is still the main challenge to achieve the industrialization of the DRM process. (1) CH 4 + CO 2 → 2 H 2 + 2 CO , ∆ H 298 K = + 247 kJ ∙ mol − 1 On the basis of the available literature, the bi-functional mechanism of Ni catalyst for DRM has reached the extensive consensus [3–5]. Specifically, CH4 dissociation, which is closely related to carbon formation, occurs on the active Ni metal surface; while CO2 activation, which is responsible for carbon elimination, proceeds on the Lewis basic sites, oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl species over the support and/or the metal-support interface. The rate of CH4 dissociation is unexpectedly higher than that of CO2 activation, which is the intrinsic reason to cause carbon deposition. One of the proposed solving strategies is to improve the ability of CO2 activation so as to narrow the rate gap between carbon formation and elimination, finally accomplishing the robust stability of the employed catalyst. Wherein, regulation to the support properties, such as alkalinity, oxygen species, oxygen vacancies, have taken one step ahead and make significant progress. The alkali or alkaline earth metals as the promotors/supports to enhance the carbon resistant ability has been widely stated in the previous reports [6–9]. Besides, researchers have paid more attention to unravel the role of the oxygen species over the catalyst surface on accelerating CO2 activation [10–14]. Therein, researchers have well pointed out that the oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl oxygen species are beneficial for CO2 adsorption and activation [13–17]. The active (bi)carbonate and formate species (labelled as Surface Adsorbed Oxygen Species, SAOS) produced by adsorbing CO2 molecules on the vacancies and hydroxyl can readily remove the carbon species, which is helpful for the enhanced stability. Additionally, due to the different active sites for CH4 dissociation and CO2 activation, the spillover effect of the SAOS from the support to the metal surface or the metal-support interface has also been well elucidated by Yentekakis et al. [17]. That is, they have realized that increasing the content of the SAOS and/or facilitating the spillover of the SAOS are very effective means for restraining carbon deposition. Regulating the metal-support interaction can modulate the properties of the metal-support interface, thereby accelerating the formation of oxygen vacancies and the spillover process of the SAOS [18–20]. Generally, the content of oxygen vacancies has the positive relation with the content of the active SAOS [17,21–23]. Safavinia et al. [12] have indicated that the subsurface Ni dopants with high dispersion can resulted in the formation of oxygen vacancies, thereby enhancing the DRM performance. Isaifan et al. [24–26] have clarified that ethylene and carbon monoxide can be even oxidized under the oxygen-free environment due to the fact that O2 - spillover from the yttria-stabilized zirconia support and the catalyst with the small Pt nanoparticles has rich metal-support interfaces, accompanied by the prominent spillover effect. ZrO2 has been widely employed as the support for DRM due to its suitable acid-base and redox properties [27–30]. In our previous work [10], the calcination atmosphere was also introduced to tune the distribution of the oxygen species over the ZrO2 support surface and the pre-treatment of H2 atmosphere was verified to be beneficial for the formation of the SAOS, which was helpful for the enhanced performance and carbon-resistant ability. Additionally, doping the transition metal, such as Ce, La, Sm, Pr and Y, etc. is also efficient to enrich the SAOS over the ZrO2-based support [22,31–33]. Especially, Y is one of the most used rare earth elements to partially stabilized ZrO2 due to the lower chemical valence of Y3+ than Zr4+ and the approximate ionic radius of Y3+ and Zr4+ [34,35]. Based on the Kröger-Vink notation [36,37], the negatively charged defects derived from the substitutional Zr by Y require the presence of the positively charged oxygen vacancies for charge compensation. Therefore, Y stabilized ZrO2 (YSZ) and Ni/YSZ materials are commonly applied as electrolyte and fuel electrode, respectively, in solid oxide fuel cells [38,39]. According to the available reports [35,40], the suitable molar ratio of Y in YSZ materials is 8% to achieve the high ionic conductivity and thermal stability. Besides, due to the enhanced CO2 activation by oxygen vacancies and the stabilized effects of the added Y on the metastable ZrO2 structure, the widespread investigation of in DRM has also been reported [41–44]. Herein, different from the metal doping in the support and the modulation on metal-support interaction to tune the content and spillover behavior of the SAOS, we regulated the interaction between Y and Zr in the Y2O3-ZrO2 composite oxide supports by changing the zirconium precursors. The effects of the zirconium precursors on the structure and properties of the Y2O3-ZrO2 supports were systematically characterized and studied. Besides, the physicochemical properties of the active metal Ni were investigated. Moreover, the effects of the content and spillover behavior of the SAOS on the DRM performance and carbon deposition over the Ni/Y2O3-ZrO2 catalysts with different zirconium precursors were discussed in depth. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zirconium dioxide (ZrO2, purity 99.99%) and zirconium hydroxide (ZrO4H4, purity 97%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Zirconium oxynitrate dihydrate (ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O, purity 45.0% which was determined by ZrO2) was purchased from Tianjin Jinke Fine Chemical Research Institute. Nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, purity 98.0%) and yttrium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Y(NO3)3·6H2O, purity 99.0%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). Sodium carbonate anhydrous (Na2CO3, purity 99.8%), ammonia solution (NH3 25–28 wt%) and ethanol (purity 99.7%) were purchased from Tianjin Feng Chuan Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. The deionized water used was prepared by an ultrapure purification system. The materials used in this investigation were without further purification. 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Support preparation The support named Y25Z75-ZrO2 was prepared by the following procedure. Firstly, the purchased ZrO2 was calcined in the muffle furnace at 700 °C for 4 h to stabilize its structure as indicated by our previous work [22]. Then, the obtained ZrO2 powder with a stoichiometric ratio was added into the pre-configured Y(NO3)3 solution (c(Y3++Zr4+=0.5 M, n(Y3+)/n(Zr4+)= 25/75). Subsequently, the ammonia solution was dripped into the suspension solution to adjust the pH value to ~10. The resulting suspension was sealed with the plastic wrap and stirred for 2 h. Finally, the filter cake, which was washed several times by the distilled water and ethanol, was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at 700 °C for 4 h (heating rate: 2 °C·min−1) to obtain Y25Z75-ZrO2 support. The supports named Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and Y25Z75-CP were prepared using the same method with Y25Z75-ZrO2 support, except that the added ZrO2 powder was switched to the purchased Zr(OH)4 powder and ZrO(NO3)2·2H.2 H2O. 2.2.2 Catalyst preparation The supported Ni catalysts (NY25Z75) were prepared via the deposition-precipitation method and the detailed synthesis procedures were referred to our previous paper [10], where the only difference was the nominal Ni loading in the present investigation was 5 wt%. The obtained catalyst was simplified as Ns, where s represented the label of the support. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectra were performed using the Agilent Cary 300 spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were carried out on Rigaku MiniFlex II X-ray diffractometer, which was equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). N2-physisorption measurement was conducted on Micromeritics ASAP 2020 at −196 °C. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) models were used to calculate the specific surface area and pore size distribution, respectively. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were produced on JEOL JEM-2100. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were recorded on JSM-7001 F equipped with QX200 EDS. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on the AXIS ULTRA DLD X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with an excited electron monochromatized Al Kα source (hυ = 1486.6 eV). The binding energies (BEs) were corrected by the C 1 s peak (284.8 eV). Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) to determine the actual Ni content in the reduced catalysts was performed on the Varian ICP-OES 720 spectrometer. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD), CO2-TPD, O2-TPD and CH4 temperature programmed surface reaction (CH4-TPSR) measurements were operated using the same procedures in the previous report [22]. The calculation equations of Ni dispersion on the basis of H2-TPD and ICP-OES as well as the turnover frequency (TOF) value of CH4 were given in supporting information. Raman spectrum was obtained on the Horiba LabRam HR-UV800/Jobin-Yvon spectrometer with He-Ne laser (λ = 632.8 nm). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on Rigaku TG-8120 and the first-derivative TGA curve was the differential thermogravimetry (DTG) profile. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was recorded on Bruker Tensor 27. The spectrum was obtained in the range of 1000–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 64 scans and 4 cm−1 each. The samples were firstly pretreated under the flow of 10% H2/Ar (v/v, 30 mL/min) at 700 °C for 60 min and then cooled to 50 °C and exposed to CO2. 2.4 Catalyst activity evaluation The activity of the employed Ni catalyst for the DRM reaction was carried out on a quartz fixed-bed microreactor (Φ 8 mm) system at atmospheric pressure. Prior to each run, the catalyst of 200 mg (20–40 meshes), diluted with the quartz sand (20–40 meshes) of 1 000 mg, was firstly reduced at 700 °C for 60 min under the flow of 10% H2/Ar (v/v, 30 mL/min). Subsequently, when the temperature of the reactor was modulated to the set value under the Ar flow, the mixture gas of CH4 and CO2 (v/v = 1/1) was introduced into the reactor. An online gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and TDX-01 chromatographic column was used to analyze the components of the effluent gas. CH4 and CO2 conversions and H2/CO ratio were calculated as Eqs. (2–4): (2) CH 4 conversion % = F in , CH 4 − F out , CH 4 F in , CH 4 × 100 % (3) CO 2 conversion % = F in , CO 2 − F out , CO 2 F in , CO 2 × 100 % (4) H 2 / CO ratio = F out , CO F out , H 2 where, F in , CH 4 and F in , CO 2 were the flow rate (mL·h−1) of CH4 and CO2, respectively, in the inlet feed; F out , CH 4 , F out , CO 2 , F out , H 2 and F out , CO were the flow rate (mL·h−1) of CH4, CO2, H2 and CO, respectively, in the outlet feed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology of the Y25Z75 supports Fig. 1a gives the UV-Vis spectra of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors. It is noted that the purchased ZrO2 after calcination and the Y25Z75-ZrO2 support exhibit the bands at 205 and 230 nm, which indicates that the addition of Y to ZrO2 does not change the ZrO2 structure in the Y25Z75-ZrO2 support; while the Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and Y25Z75-CP supports only possess the band at 205 nm, which implies that the addition of Y influences the ZrO2 structure. These phenomena reveal that the interaction between Y and Zr in the Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and Y25Z75-CP supports is relatively strong than that in the Y25Z75-ZrO2 support. Fig. 1b shows the PXRD patterns of Zr(OH)4 and ZrO2 samples (ZrO2-Ⅰ and ⅠⅠ are obtained by calcining the purchased Zr(OH)4 and ZrO2, respectively). Notably, the purchased Zr(OH)4 sample displays an amorphous structure while ZrO2 samples possess the typical diffraction peaks of monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, JCPDS 37–1484). Fig. 1c displays the PXRD patterns of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors. The Y25Z75-ZrO2 support is indexed with the diffraction peaks of m-ZrO2 and cubic Y2O3 (c-Y2O3, JCPDS 41–1105). The Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 support exhibits the diffraction peaks of tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2, JCPDS 79–1769) and c-Y2O3. Compared with the PXRD pattern of ZrO2-Ⅰ (Fig. 1b), the existence of the metastable t-ZrO2 in Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 suggests that the added Y somewhat stabilizes the metastable structure of ZrO2. Further, Y25Z75-CP only exhibits the diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2, further indicating the enhanced stabilizing effect on the sample with ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O as the precursor. Besides, the peaks on the patterns of Y25Z75-CP shift to the lower degree, which might be due to the insertion of Y to t-ZrO2 crystalline lattice. In combination with the UV-Vis results, these phenomena illustrate that the added Y element does not influence the ZrO2 structure when using the pre-stabilized ZrO2 as the zirconium precursor; however, if Zr(OH)4 and ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O are employed as the zirconium precursors, the Y element is capable to effectively stabilize the metastable ZrO2 structure via enhancing Y-Zr interaction. Table 1 gives the crystalline size of ZrO2 and Y2O3 calculated using the Scherrer formula based on the patterns shown in Fig. 1 c. The crystalline size of ZrO2 on the Y25Z75 supports exhibits the following order: Y25Z75-ZrO2 > Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 > Y25Z75-CP, which suggests that the Y-Zr interaction inhibits the growth of ZrO2 particles under the high-temperature calcination. Note that the crystalline size of Y2O3 on the Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 support is larger than that on Y25Z75-ZrO2, which might be caused by the partially overlap of the diffraction peaks for m-ZrO2 (−1 1 1), t-ZrO2 (1 0 1) and c-Y2O3 (2 2 2). It is well known that the high-temperature treatment will lead to the particle sintering and phase transition of ZrO2 [11,27,45]. As with Zr(OH)4, the direct high-temperature calcination results in the formation of m-ZrO2 (ZrO2-Ⅰ in Fig. 1b), which is the stable crystalline structure. According to the previous reports [27,44], reflux and impurity doping can effectively inhibit the phase transition from the metastable tetragonal and amorphous structure due to the reduction of particle size. Here, the doped Y is efficient to decrease the size of ZrO2 below the critical size for phase transition. Thus, Y25Z75-CP with more Y inserting into the ZrO2 lattice exhibits more stable tetragonal structure and smaller particles. To further view the morphology of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors, the TEM images of the supports were produced and the obtained images are shown in Figs. 1d-f. Fig. S1 gives the TEM images of the calcined ZrO2 sample. In combination with the particle size distribution in Figs. S2a and S3 , it is observable that the Y25Z75-ZrO2 support consists of large particles of ZrO2 and small particles of Y2O3, which has good agreement with the XRD data (Table 1). However, as for Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and Y25Z75-CP, the difference between Y2O3 and ZrO2 is invisible. Compared to the particle size distributions shown in Figs. S2a and S2b, also identified by XRD (Table 1), the particle size of ZrO2 on the Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 support obviously decreases, indicating that the crystalline transformation and the sintering of ZrO2 are furthest suppressed due to the Y-Zr interaction. In case of the Y25Z75-CP support, the particle accumulation is the densest, and prone to form the spongy porous structure which might be due to the formation of the Y2O3-ZrO2 solid solution. The HAADF-STEM images and EDS-mapping of the Y25Z75 supports shown in Fig. S4 further verify the aforementioned analysis. Figs. 2a and 2b display the N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the Y25Z75 supports with different zirconium precursors, respectively. The Y25Z75 supports possesses IV type isotherms with H3 type hysteresis loop at relatively high pressure, indicating its poor mesoporous characteristics [46]. The hysteresis loop on the Y25Z75-CP support is H2 type hysteresis loop, which illustrates that the mesoporous structure is regular. The hysteresis loop on the Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 support lies between the two supports mentioned above, as indicated by their pore size distributions (Fig. 2b). From the textural parameters listed in Table 1, although the specific surface area of the Y25Z75-ZrO2 support is the smallest, its pore volume is the largest; whereas, the mesoporous channels of the Y25Z75-ZrO2 support are not well developed. It is deduced that the pore volume might be derived from the stacking of the small Y2O3 particles and the large ZrO2 particles. The specific surface area of the Y25Z75-CP support is the largest and the pore channels are uniform mesoporous. Thus, the pore volume in Table 1 is originated from the contribution of mesoporous. The specific surface area and pore volume of the Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 support are intermediate between Y25Z75-ZrO2 and Y25Z75-CP, and the pore channels are comprised of the mesoporous pores and the accumulated pores. 3.2 Structure and morphology of the Ni/Y25Z75 catalysts As shown in Figs. 2c and 2d are the N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the NY25Z75 catalysts. Compared with the corresponding results displayed in Figs. 2a and 2b, the introduction of Ni does not seemingly change the pore structures of the supports. In Table 2, the specific surface areas of NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 are larger than that of the corresponding supports, indicating that the accumulation of Ni particles on the support surface somewhat increases the specific surface area of the catalyst. The specific surface area of the NY25Z75-CP catalyst is smaller than that of the Y25Z75-CP support, suggesting that Ni particles enter into the pore channels of the support, and partially block the pores. PXRD patterns of the fresh and reduced NY25Z75 catalysts with different zirconium precursors are shown in Figs. 3a and 3b, respectively. Compared with the patterns shown in Fig. 1c, the structure of the Y25Z75 support does not change remarkably after Ni loading and the reduction. The diffraction peaks of NiO (JCPDS 78–0429, 2θ = 43.3°) and c-Y2O3, Ni (JCPDS 04–085, 2θ = 44.5°) and m-ZrO2 are partially overlapped. However, the intensity of the diffraction peaks at the overlap in Figs. 3a and 3b is higher than the intensity of the corresponding diffraction peaks in Fig. 1c, suggesting that the diffraction peaks of NiO and Ni appear on the fresh and reduced NY25Z75 catalysts, respectively. Note that the sharpest diffraction peaks for Ni are observed on the NY25Z75-CP catalyst (Fig. 3b), illustrating that coprecipitation preparation method is not conductive to Ni dispersion (Table 2). To further clarify the distribution of Ni particle size on the NY25Z75 catalysts, TEM images are shown in Figs. 3c-e. Ni particles on NY25Z75-ZrO2 are mainly concentrated near the relatively small Y2O3 particles, and the size has a wide distribution range (Fig. 3f). For NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4, the particle size of ZrO2 and Y2O3 is too close to be distinguished clear. Thus, the distribution position of Ni particles is difficult to be determined, but the size distribution is more concentrated (Fig. 3g). Additionally, the morphology of the NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalyst is visibly different from that of the corresponding support, which might be due to the interaction between Ni and Y2O3, which is not fully incorporated in ZrO2. NY25Z75-CP catalyst presents the widest Ni particle size distribution range, including small Ni particles in the mesoporous channels and large particles formed by the aggregation (Fig. 3h). Table 2 lists the Ni particle average size in statistic according to the TEM results. As observed, the sizes on NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 are almost the same, while that on NY25Z75-CP catalyst is larger. This indicates that the distribution of Ni particles on NY25Z75 is not related to the textural properties and crystal structure but closely affected by the existence of the isolated Y2O3. Further, we calculated the dispersion and size of Ni particles according to the ICP-OES and H2-TPD results ( Table 3). It also indicates the sequence of Ni dispersion and particle size on the representative supports determined by the XRD and TEM characterizations. 3.3 Surface chemical state of the Ni/Y25Z75 catalysts Figs. S5a and 4a show the CO2-TPD profiles of the reduced Y25Z75 supports and NY25Z75 catalysts, respectively. Observably, there are two CO2 desorption peaks located in the range of 50–300 °C and 300–500 °C for the three representative samples in both figures, which are assigned to the weak alkaline sites and the medium-strong alkaline sites, respectively. Although the number of the weak and medium-strong alkaline sites over the supports follows in the order: Y25Z75-ZrO2 > Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 > Y25Z75-CP, the number of the strong alkaline sites shows an opposite order. The sequence of the alkaline sites for the catalysts also displays the same trend. More weak alkaline sites on Y25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-ZrO2 might be due to the fact that Y2O3 exhibits stronger intrinsic alkalinity than ZrO2 [47]. Factually, t-ZrO2 possesses more medium-strong basic sites than m-ZrO2 [27,48,49]. Thus, more medium-strong basic sites on Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and Y25Z75-CP, as well as NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and NY25Z75-CP, could be ascribed to the formation of t-ZrO2 stabilized by Y2O3. Overall, Y25Z75-CP (NY25Z75-CP) exhibits the most alkaline sites and the strongest alkalinity, followed by Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 (NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4) and Y25Z75-ZrO2 (NY25Z75-ZrO2), indicating that the enhanced interaction between Y and Zr can improve the alkalinity of the Ni catalyst supported by Y2O3-ZrO2 composites. Figs. S5b and 4b show the O2-TPD profiles of the reduced Y25Z75 supports and NY25Z75 catalysts, respectively. The detected desorption signal could be separated to α-oxygen at lower temperatures, which corresponds to weakly bonded adsorbed oxygen species (e.g. on oxygen vacancies) and β-oxygen at higher temperatures, which corresponds to oxygen removed from the metal-oxide lattice and correlates with the oxygen mobility [23,50]. The content of the adsorbed oxygen species (including both α-oxygen and β-oxygen) over the reduced Y25Z75 supports and NY25Z75 catalysts is in the order of Y25Z75-ZrO2 (NY25Z75-ZrO2) > Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 (NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4) > Y25Z75-CP (NY25Z75-CP). Some previous researchers have revealed that the adsorbed oxygen species have positive correlation with oxygen vacancies [21,50,51]. Therefore, it is plausible that the Y25Z75-ZrO2 (NY25Z75-ZrO2) catalyst has the most oxygen vacancies among the present three catalysts. Although some reports have stated that the catalyst with stronger O2 adsorption ability generally possesses the stronger CO2 adsorption ability [22,52], it should be pointed out that the CO2 adsorption ability of the catalysts in this study does not has the direct relation with their O2 adsorption ability. After all, the former is responsible for the alkalinity, while the latter is related to oxygen vacancy. Fig. 4c and Table 4 give the XPS spectra of O 1s on the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts and the fitting results, respectively. As clarified in the open literature [24,53], the oxygen species with the binding energy at around 531.3 eV (Oβ) and above 532.0 eV (Oγ) are ascribed to the SAOS, while the oxygen species with the biding energy at around 529.5 eV (Oα) are corresponded to the lattice oxygen species. Here, it can be noted that the content of the SAOS (the area of Oβ +Oγ, Table 4) over the NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst is the highest, followed by the NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalyst, and the content of the SAOS on the NY25Z75-CP catalyst is the lowest. Particularly, Oβ are considered to be closely related to the content of oxygen vacancies and Oγ are assigned to the hydroxyl oxygen species or the physisorbed H2O molecules. Thus, on the basis of the data in Table 4, the NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst possesses the most oxygen vacancies, while the NY25Z75-CP catalyst has the fewest oxygen vacancies, which is in agreement with the O2-TPD results. However, the order of the Oγ content over the NY25Z75 catalysts shows an opposite arrangement, indicating that the enhanced interaction between Y and Zr promotes the formation of hydroxyl group. In combination the results of CO2-TPD, it seems that the improved alkalinity over the NY25Z75-CP catalyst might be derived from the increased Oγ, which are also identified as the CO2 adsorption sites [16,54,55]. Figs. S6a and S6b give the XPS spectra Zr 3d and Y 3d on the reduced bare Y25Z75 supports, respectively. Fig. 5a and 5b show the XPS spectra of Zr 3d and Y 3d on the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts, respectively. The lower the binding energy of the metal oxide element, the more charge is transferred from other elements to the metal element, that is, the deeper the reduction degree of the support. As noted from Figs. S6, 5a, and 5b, the binding energy of Zr and Y on the surface of the Y25Z75 supports and NY25Z75 catalysts displays the following order: NY25Z75-ZrO2 < NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 < NY25Z75-CP. Apparently, the reduction degree of Zr and Y has an inverse trend. In combination with the data about the SAOS, it can be concluded that the higher the content of the SAOS, the deeper the reduction degree of Zr and Y. Fig. S7 displays the XPS spectra of O 1s on the reduced ZrO2 samples obtained from the different zirconium precursors. It is noted that the adsorbed and lattice oxygen species over the bare ZrO2 show slight difference, and even the content of the SAOS over the ZrO2 derived from ZrO(NO3)2 is the highest, which is distinct with the data in Fig. 4c. Therefore, the differences of the SAOS on the NY25Z75 catalysts can be not ascribed to the different precursors but the interaction between Y and zirconium precursors. The spectra of O1s and Zr 3d shown in Figs. S7 and S8, respectively, illustrate that there is similar status of the existing species on the prepared ZrO2 samples in spite of different precursors. Comparing the spectra of Zr 3d (Fig. S8) and Y3d (Fig. S9) on ZrO2 and Y2O3 with the corresponding spectra of Zr 3d (Fig. 5a) and Y3d (Fig. 5b) on the Y25Z75 samples, it further confirmed that the Y dopant induces the changes of Y-Zr interaction and the surface chemistry in the NY25Z75 catalysts. Displayed in Fig. 5c are the XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 on the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts. The peak at 852.87 eV is assigned to the metallic Ni0 species [56,57]. The characteristic peaks at 855.43 Ni2+ species, and the peak at 861.00 eV is its satellite peak [56,57], which are derived from the re-oxidized Ni0 species by the inevitable air. It is observed that the binding energies of Ni0 and Ni2+ on the NY25Z75 catalysts are approximate, indicating that the chemical states of the reduced Ni species on the catalyst surface are similar. Fig. 5d describes the H2-TPR profiles of the fresh NY25Z75 catalysts with different zirconium sources. The reduction peaks of NiO on the NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts are similar. Whereas, compared with the above two catalysts, the reduction peak temperature of NiO on the NY25Z75-CP catalyst shifts to the lower temperature. These phenomena indicate that the morphology, crystal structure and textural properties of the support limitedly influence on the dispersion and chemical states of NiO. Actually, the enhanced metal-support interaction on the NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts might be ascribed to the formation of the solid solution structure derived from NiO and the isolated Y2O3. Although the enhanced metal-support interaction promotes Ni dispersion (Table 3), it does not affect the chemical state of the reduced Ni species (Fig. 5c). According to the comprehensive results of the TEM, H2-TPR/TPD and XPS techniques, the NiO species are preferred to interact with the isolated Y2O3 over the catalyst surface, enhancing the metal-support interaction. Thus, it is easily understood that Ni dispersion on the Y25Z75-ZrO2 and Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 supports is approximate, and even higher than that on Y25Z75-CP support with larger specific surface area and more developed pore structure. The profiles of CH4-TPSR over the reduced NY25Z75 catalysts are shown in Fig. 6. As observed in Figs. 6a and 6b, the reduced NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts with the similar Ni dispersion and chemical states (Table 3 and Fig. 5c) exhibit the different ability to decompose CH4 molecules, where, obviously, the former possesses the stronger capacity for CH4 dissociation. It has been well identified that both the high Ni dispersion and the abundant SAOS can promote CH4 dissociation [8,12,58]. Additionally, some available reports have pointed out that the partially reduced support is capable to facilitate CH4 dissociation to some extent [10,59]. Thus, the higher content of the SAOS (Fig. 4c) and the deeper reduction degree of Y and Zr (Figs. 5a and 5b) over the NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst reasonably induce the stronger ability to decompose CH4. Notably, the initial temperature of CH4 dissociation over the NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalyst (320 °C) is lower than that over the NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst (375 °C), which might be due to that the mobility of the SAOS over the former is easier than that over the latter. NY25Z75-CP catalyst has low Ni dispersion, few SAOS and poor reduction degree of Y and Zr, which result in the weakest ability for CH4 dissociation. Moreover, the catalyst with higher Ni dispersion and more SAOS have a wider temperature window for CH4 dissociation, suggesting the stronger carbon resistant ability. From Figs. 6c and 6d, the detected CO2 and CO, originated from the oxidized carbonous species, are synchronously generated with H2. Seemingly, the higher the content of the SAOS over the catalyst, the more the produced CO2 and CO; and the more active the SAOS, the lower the initial temperature for the produced CO2 and CO. The results demonstrate convincingly that the spillover process of the SAOS occurs. Besides, as the reaction proceeds, CO2 is no longer detected, indicating that the active SAOS with relatively strong oxidizing ability are depleted. The experimental phenomenon that only CO is detected in the outlet illustrates that the oxidizing ability of the lattice oxygen species is limited though they can migrate to oxidize the carbonous species. The deposited carbon, which cannot be eliminated by the oxygen species, cover the active sites of the catalyst, resulting in the weakened ability to decompose CH4, also indicated by an adverse volcano for the signal of CH4 (Fig. 6a). 3.4 DRM reaction behavior over the Ni/Y25Z75 catalysts Figs. 7a and 7b show the initial conversions of CH4 and CO2 over NY25Z75 catalyst at different reaction temperatures. Obviously, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 gradually increase with the raising temperature, since DRM is an endothermic reaction and the increased temperature is conducive to the forward reaction. In addition, the initial conversions of CH4 and CO2 over the NY25Z75 catalysts display the following order: NY25Z75-ZrO2 > NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 > NY25Z75-CP. According to the previous discussion, the dispersion and chemical state of Ni on the NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts are similar, so the different initial activity of the two catalysts can be reasonably ascribed to the content of the SAOS. The NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst with higher content of the SAOS deservedly has better initial activity. The NY25Z75-CP catalyst exhibits the lowest initial activity due to its relatively low Ni dispersion, weak metal-support interaction and few SAOS. Additionally, CH4 conversion is always lower than CO2 conversion, suggesting the occurrence of the side-reaction (Reverse water-gas shift, RWGS, Eq. 5), which is also indicated by H2/CO ratio (Fig. 7c). Moreover, H2/CO ratio shows an upward trend with the increased temperature, which elucidates that DRM is dominant at high temperature. (5) H 2 + CO 2 → H 2 O + CO , ∆ H 298 K = + 41 kJ ∙ mol − 1 In accordance with the initial activity sequence shown in Figs. 7a and 7b, the NY25Z75-CP catalyst exhibits the lowest CH4 and CO2 conversions during the investigated period as displayed in Figs. 7d and 7e. Although the initial activity of NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst is higher than that of NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalyst, the deactivation rate of the former is significantly faster than that of the latter. Generally, DRM reaction behavior, especially carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, is mainly affected by Ni dispersion [51,60,61] and support properties [10,27,62], such as SAOS, which are able to more strongly promote CH4 dissociation than CO2 activation [22]. With respect to the present study, since similar dispersion and chemical state of Ni are observable over the NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts, it is plausible that the SAOS might be considered to be an assignable cause of their different reaction behaviors with time on stream. Wherein, the rate gap between CH4 dissociation and CO2 activation on the NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst with more SAOS should be enlarged, resulting in the more carbon deposition at the initial reaction stage, which is the main cause to the rapid decline in its activity. As shown in Fig. 7f, the H2/CO ratio over the NY25Z75-CP catalyst is much lower than that over the NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts. This indicates that the RWGS reaction proceeds over NY25Z75-CP easily. The initial H2/CO ratio over NY25Z75-ZrO2 is higher than that over NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4, which is attributed to the fact that more SAOS over the former promote CH4 dissociation, apparently, accompanied by more carbon deposition. 3.5 Carbon deposition behavior over the Ni/Y25Z75 catalysts As shown in Fig. 8a is the XRD patterns of the NY25Z75 catalyst after the activity evaluation. Compared with the reduced catalysts (Fig. 3b), the significant diffraction peak of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) is observable on the spent catalyst surface, indicating that carbon deposition has proceeded during the DRM reaction. Fig. S10 gives the TEM images of the spent catalysts. No significant growth of Ni particles is observed and carbon deposition mainly consists of MWCNTs, which agrees with the XRD results. Table S1 lists the surface Ni concentration over the reduced and spent NY25Z75 catalysts measured by the XPS technique. Apparently, the concentration of the surface Ni species over the spent catalysts is much lower than that over the reduced catalysts but the concentration of the carbon species significantly increases. The results are in accord with the XRD data and carbon deposition deactivates the catalyst due to the coverage of the active sites. Fig. 8b shows the Raman spectra of the spent NY25Z75 catalysts to character the nature of the deposited carbon. Generally, the ratio of the G to D band intensity (IG/ID) is used to as an indicator of the graphitization degree for carbon deposition. The greater the IG/ID value, the deeper the graphitization degree of carbon deposition, namely, the higher the chemical inertness of carbon deposition [62,63]. Turning to the present catalysts, carbon deposition on NY25Z75-ZrO2, NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and NY25Z75-CP gives the IG/ID values of 0.96, 0.82 and 1.06, respectively. This suggests that higher Ni dispersion and more SAOS are certainly beneficial to reduce the chemical inertness of carbon deposition. Slight higher ratio of IG/ID over NY25Z75-ZrO2 than that over NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 indicates that carbon deposition, if not be removed in time, easily leads to the rapid deactivation at the initial reaction stage, and finally become more inert at the subsequent reaction process. The TG technique is also employed to evaluate the amount and property of carbon deposition, and the TG and DTG profiles of the spent NY25Z75 catalysts are displayed in Figs. 8c and 8d, respectively. From Fig. 8c, the amount of carbon deposition on the NY25Z75-ZrO2 catalyst is the largest (42%), followed by the NY25Z75-CP catalyst (37%), and the amount of carbon deposition on the NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalyst is the smallest (34%). The results powerfully demonstrate the evolution of the catalytic activity. Consistent with the above discussion, high Ni dispersion is beneficial to inhibit the formation of carbon deposition (NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and NY25Z75-CP), while the abundant SAOS are able to promote the cracking of CH4 and lead to more carbon deposition (NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4). Although carbon deposition on the spent NY25Z75-CP catalyst is less than that on NY25Z75-ZrO2, the removal temperature (Fig. 8d) is higher, suggesting the deeper chemical inertness. However, the removal temperatures of carbon deposition on the spent NY25Z75-ZrO2 and Ny25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts are similar, indicating that the types of carbon deposition are the same. 3.6 Discussion This study regulated the structure and properties of the Y2O3-ZrO2 supports via changing the zirconium precursors. The addition of Y into the different zirconium precursors leads to the different interaction between Y and Zr in the obtained Y2O3-ZrO2 composites, thereby affecting the structure, morphology and surface properties of the Y2O3-ZrO2 supports. However, the differences in the structure and morphology of the Y2O3-ZrO2 supports seem to have no great impacts on the dispersion and chemical state of the supported Ni species. Factually, the existence of the isolated Y2O3 is the fundamental factor to determine Ni dispersion due to the enhanced metal-support interaction. Fig. S11 shows the performance of the Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/Y2O3 catalysts. It is noted that the Ni/Y2O3 catalyst exhibits the superior performance than the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst in terms of the conversions of CH4 and CO2, H2/CO ratio, and robust stability. As aforementioned, due to the formation of Ni and Y2O3 solid solution structure, the enhanced metal-support interaction can greatly promote Ni dispersion. As a result, the size of Ni particles on Ni/Y2O3 is smaller than that on Ni/ZrO2, which might be the main reason for its high conversion and H2/CO ratio. Furthermore, high Ni dispersion and strong metal-support interaction over the Ni/Y2O3 catalyst mean the improved carbon resistance and anti-sintering ability, thereby strengthening the stability. The selected zirconium precursor directly affects the existing state of Y modifier on the surface of ZrO2. The catalyst with ZrO2 as the zirconium precursor possesses the highest content of the SAOS, followed by the catalysts with Zr(OH)4 and ZrO(NO3)2·2H.2 H2O as the zirconium precursors. Thereafter, the adsorption of CO2 is not only related to the content of the SAOS, but also affected by the structural properties. To further unravel the effects of the SAOS on CO2 adsorption, the DRIFTS were recorded and shown in Fig. S12. The bands at 1645, 1445 and 1225 cm−1 are attributed to the characterization of bicarbonate species (b-HCO3 -), where the former two bands are the asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching vibrational modes (νas(CO3) and νs(CO3)), respectively, and the latter is ascribed to δ(OH) [22,49,64]. The bands at 1425 cm−1 might be for ionic bicarbonate species (i-HCO3 -) [64]. The bands at 1580, 1560, 1340 and 1332 cm−1 are assigned to the vibrations of bridged and bidentate carbonate species (b-CO3 2-) [22,49]. The bands at 1362 cm−1 are corresponded to the vibration of monodentate carbonate species (m-CO3 2-) [22,64]. It is noted that Y25Z75-ZrO2 exhibits the most active carbonate species, which is in good agreement with the highest content of the SAOS. The intensity of b-HCO3 - on Y25Z75-CP is the strongest, which implying the highest hydroxyl species. These results are in accordance with the XPS results and further identify that the catalyst with abundant SAOS seems to be efficient to activate CO2 via producing more active carbonate species. High Ni dispersion and abundant SAOS are beneficial to the improvement of catalyst activity caused by the promoted CH4 dissociation and stimulative CO2 activation. However, when DRM is operated at the relatively low temperature, the preferred promotion of the SAOS on CH4 dissociation via the spillover will deepen the rate gap of CH4 and CO2, thereby leading to more serious carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation. Thus, balancing the formation and removal rate of the carbonous species is still of vital importance. The above discussion confirms that the spillover of the reactive oxygen species can alleviate carbon deposition to a certain extent. Whereas, the rate of CH4 dissociation is always faster than that of CO2 activation, since CO2 molecule is more inert. Therefore, increasing the temperature to promote CO2 activation, that is, enhancing the formation and migration rate of the reactive oxygen species, is conductive to the dynamic balance of carbon generation and elimination on the catalyst surface. Fig. S13 gives the reaction results of DRM at 800 °C. Obviously, the NY25Z75-ZrO2 and NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 catalysts with higher Ni dispersion exhibit the superior activity. Moreover, the stability over the former with more SAOS is quite robust. This phenomenon differed from that at 700 °C suggests that the SAOS play more significant role in reducing the rate gap between carbon formation and elimination due to their preferentially promotional effect on CO2 activation at high temperature. To further investigate the effects of the SAOS on the intrinsic activity, the TOF value of CH4 has been calculated and the results are: 0.62 s−1 for NY25Z75-ZrO2, 0.53 s−1 for NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4, 0.43 s−1 for NY25Z75-CP. Apparently, the SAOS are able to significantly increase the intrinsic activity. Besides, consistent with the previous results [26,58], the spillover of the SAOS is closely related to the Ni particle size. The catalyst with the homogeneous and highly dispersed metal exhibits the high activity of oxygen vacancies and oxygen spillover. 4 Conclusion In this study, we investigated the effects of the regulated interaction between Y and Zr via modulating the zirconium precursors on the structure, morphology and surface properties of Y2O3-ZrO2 composites. The Y-Zr interaction in Y25Z75-ZrO2 was the weakest, where the structure and morphology of ZrO2 did not change greatly before and after Y doping. Nevertheless, the doped Y was efficient to stabilize the metastable structure of t-ZrO2 when using Zr(OH)4 and ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O as the zirconium precursors due to the relatively strong Y-Zr interaction. The structure and morphology of the supports were irrelevant with the dispersion and chemical state of the active metal Ni. The isolated Y2O3 over Y25Z75-ZrO2 and Y25Z75-Zr(OH)4 enhanced the metal-support interaction, which was the key factor to determine Ni dispersion. The surface chemical properties of the catalysts obtained from the different zirconium precursors varied greatly. The content of the SAOS over NY25Z75-ZrO2 was the highest, followed by NY25Z75-Zr(OH)4 and NY25Z75-CP. The enhanced effect of the SAOS on CH4 dissociation via the spillover process, especially at low temperature, was more remarkable than that on CO2 activation. As a result, the catalyst with more SAOS suffered from more carbon deactivation and quicker deactivation despite it showed relatively high activity. Due to the stimulative effects on CO2 activation by the SAOS and the accelerated spillover of the reactive oxygen species at high temperature, the formation and elimination rate of the carbonous species would be balanced, thereby improving the activity and stability. This study provides a deeper comprehension on the bifunctional mechanism of DRM and the spillover effects of the reactive oxygen species on the behavior of carbon deposition. coredata.dc:description: The surface reactive oxygen species over Y2O3-ZrO2 supports were tuned by regulating the interaction between Y and Zr via modulating the zirconium precursors. It was revealed that the content of the surface adsorbed oxygen species (SAOS) over the catalyst with ZrO2 precursor was the highest, followed by the catalysts with Zr(OH)4 and ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O precursors. The difference of the Y-Zr interaction influenced the reactive oxygen species and the support structure and morphology. However, Ni dispersion was determined by the existence of the isolated Y2O3 due to the enhanced metal-support interaction. High Ni dispersion and abundant surface adsorbed oxygen species were beneficial to promote CH4 and CO2 reactivity. Nevertheless, CH4 dissociation facilitated by the SAOS was more remarkable than CO2 activation at low temperature. Thus, the improvement of the SAOS on carbon-resistant ability of the catalyst was only achieved at high temperature through balancing the carbon formation and elimination.
coredata.dc:title: Dry reforming of methane over the Ni/Y2O3-ZrO2 catalysts: Effects of the tunable surface oxygen species by modulating the zirconium precursors
